questions.text: Scope of modern Family Planning services include all the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Modern family planning services typically encompass a range of reproductive health services aimed at assisting individuals and couples in making informed decisions about the timing and spacing of pregnancies. These services aim to promote reproductive health and well-being, prevent unintended pregnancies, and provide support for individuals and families in achieving their desired family size.

Explanation for other options:

a. Screening for cervical cancer:

Many modern family planning services include screening for cervical cancer as part of comprehensive reproductive health care. Cervical cancer screening, typically performed through Pap smears or HPV testing, helps detect precancerous changes or early stages of cervical cancer, allowing for timely intervention and treatment. Screening for cervical cancer is important for promoting women's health and preventing cervical cancer-related morbidity and mortality.

b. Providing services for unmarried mothers:

Modern family planning services often include providing support and services for individuals, including unmarried mothers, who seek reproductive health care. These services may include contraceptive counselling, pregnancy testing, prenatal care, childbirth services, and postnatal care. Supporting unmarried mothers is essential for promoting maternal and child health and ensuring access to reproductive health care for all individuals, regardless of marital status.

d. Providing adoption services:

While adoption services may not always be directly integrated into family planning programs, many organizations and agencies that provide modern family planning services also offer support and resources for adoption. Adoption services assist individuals and couples who are unable to conceive or choose not to have biological children in expanding their families through adoption. Providing adoption services aligns with the broader goals of promoting reproductive choice, family formation, and child welfare.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective method among the natural family planning techniques?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This method combines the temperature, cervical mucus and calendar techniques for identifying the fertile period. If the woman cannot clearly interpret one sign, she can "double check" her interpretation with another. Therefore,this method is more effective than the other natural methods.
  • By incorporating multiple indicators, the symptothermal method offers greater accuracy in identifying fertile and infertile periods compared to other natural family planning methods. It provides redundancy and cross-checking of fertility signs, enhancing its reliability and effectiveness in preventing or achieving pregnancy.

Natural Family Planning Methods:

1)Calendar Method:

  • The calendar method, also known as the rhythm method, involves tracking the length of menstrual cycles over time to predict fertile and infertile periods. However, it relies solely on past menstrual cycle data and assumes regularity in cycle length. This method is less effective compared to others because it does not account for individual variations in menstrual cycles, making it prone to inaccuracies, especially for individuals with irregular cycles. Therefore, it is not the most effective natural family planning method.(Option A ruled out)

2)Billing Method:

  • The Billing method, also known as the cervical mucus method, involves tracking changes in cervical mucus throughout the menstrual cycle to identify fertile and infertile periods. While it is more effective than the calendar method as it directly observes hormonal changes related to ovulation, its effectiveness can be influenced by factors such as vaginal infections or medications that affect cervical mucus. Therefore, it may not be as reliable as other methods, such as the symptothermal method(Option B ruled out).

3)Basal Body Temperature (BBT) Method:

  • The BBT method involves tracking basal body temperature daily to detect the slight increase in temperature that occurs after ovulation due to the release of progesterone.
  • While it is more effective than the calendar method because it directly observes the hormonal shift associated with ovulation, it may not reliably predict the fertile window in all cases. Factors such as illness, poor sleep quality, or irregular sleep patterns can affect basal body temperature, leading to inaccuracies in predicting ovulation.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Failure rate of the following technique
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image indicates Pomeroy's technique, also known as tubal ligation or tubal sterilization, a surgical procedure used for permanent contraception in women. Pomeroy's technique is highly effective in preventing pregnancy, with a failure rate typically ranging from 0.1% to 0.5% (All other options are ruled out).he failure rate may vary depending on factors such as surgical technique, surgeon experience, and individual differences in tubal anatomy.

questions.text: Most cost-effective method of Family Planning is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vasectomy is widely considered to be the most cost-effective method of family planning for several reasons:

  • Long-term effectiveness: Vasectomy is a permanent form of contraception. Once a man undergoes a vasectomy, it is highly unlikely for him to father a child. This eliminates the ongoing costs associated with other temporary methods of contraception, such as oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), which require regular refills and adherence.
  • One-time cost: Vasectomy is a simpler, faster and less expensive operation than tubectomy in terms of instruments, hospitalization and doctor's training. Cost-wise, the ratio is about 5 vasectomies to one tubal ligation.
  • Less invasive: Unlike female sterilization methods like tubectomy, vasectomy is a less invasive procedure with lower associated healthcare expenses. Tubectomy may require hospitalization and anaesthesia, which can increase overall costs. Vasectomy, on the other hand, can often be performed in an outpatient setting under local anaesthesia, reducing healthcare expenses.

Explanation for other options:

Tubectomy (Tubal ligation)(Option B):

  • Tubectomy is a surgical procedure for female sterilization that involves closing or blocking the fallopian tubes to prevent eggs from reaching the uterus for fertilization.
  • While tubectomy is highly effective, it may involve higher initial costs and potential complications compared to vasectomy. Additionally, tubectomy may require hospitalization and anaesthesia, leading to higher healthcare expenses.

Copper T(Option C):

  • Copper T (Intrauterine Device or IUD) is a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC) method that is highly effective at preventing pregnancy. While Copper T may have a higher initial cost compared to vasectomy, it can provide cost savings over time due to its long duration of effectiveness (up to 10 years). However, the cost-effectiveness of Copper T may vary depending on factors such as healthcare infrastructure, access to services, and individual preferences.

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)(Option D)

  • OCPs are a popular contraceptive method that involves taking daily pills containing hormones to prevent pregnancy. While OCPs are effective and convenient for many individuals, they involve ongoing costs for prescription refills and healthcare visits. Over a lifetime, these recurring costs can add up and may surpass the initial cost of vasectomy, making vasectomy a more cost-effective option in the long run.

questions.text: Under 1971 MTP act, MTP is allowed up to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act was enacted in 1971 in India to regulate and facilitate safe abortion services. Under this act, abortion (MTP) is legally permitted up to 24 weeks of gestation under certain conditions according to the MTP amendment 2021:

  • MTP can be done till 24 weeks
  • In case of contraceptive failure MTP done till 20 weeks only

Who Can Perform MTP

  • Only a registered medical practitioner (RMP) who has assisted in ≥25 MTPs.
  • Must be done in:
    • Govt/government-recognized hospital, or
    • Private hospital licensed by the Chief Medical Officer.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks -1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state.

questions.text:
In a village with 180 eligible couples, the contraceptive usage data is as follows:
1. Sterilization: Vasectomy -3, Tubectomy-8
2. IUD users: 10
3. OCP users: 10
4. Condom users: 29
What is the Effective Couple Protection Rate (CPR) in this population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To calculate the Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (CPR), we need to determine the percentage of eligible couples currently using a contraceptive method.

Given data:

  • Sterilization (Vasectomy): 3 couples
  • Sterilization (Tubectomy): 8 couples
  • Intrauterine Device (IUD) users: 10 couples
  • Oral Contraceptive Pill (OCP) users: 10 couples
  • Condom users: 29 couples
  • Total eligible couples: 180

Total couples using contraception = 3 (Vasectomy) + 8 (Tubectomy) + 10 (IUD) + 10 (OCP) + 29 (Condom) = 60 couples

CPR = (Total couples using contraception / Total eligible couples) * 100

CPR = (60 / 180) * 100 = 33.33%

So, the effective Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (CPR) in the village is approximately 33.33%.

questions.text: A contraceptive Z is used by 100 couples for a continuous period of 2 years. During this period 20 women become pregnant despite using it. What is the Pearl index of Z
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Pearl index is a measure of contraceptive failure rate, expressed as the number of pregnancies per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). To calculate the Pearl index, we need to determine the number of pregnancies and the total duration of exposure in woman-years.

Given:

  • Number of pregnancies (P) = 20
  • Total duration of exposure = 100 couples * 2 years = 200 woman-years

Pearl Index = ({Number of accidental Pregnancies}{Total Woman-Years of Exposure}) x 100

Pearl index = (20 / 200) * 100 = 10 per HWY (Option C)

questions.text: A contraceptive method results in a woman becoming pregnant twice over her reproductive lifespan of 25 years. What is the approximate Pearl Index for this method?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Pearl Index (PI) is a measure of contraceptive failure rate, expressed as the number of pregnancies per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

Pearl Index = (Number of accidental pregnancies / Total duration of exposure in women-years) * 100

Accidental pregnancies per woman = 2

Reproductive lifespan = 25 years

Therefore,PI=(2×100=8 (Option C)

choices.text: Abstinence is required only for a few days each month
It is associated with no financial cost
The safe period can also be determined using the temperature rhythm or cervical mucus method
Ectopic pregnancy is a reported complication

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the calendar method of contraception is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The calendar method, also known as the rhythm method, involves tracking a woman's menstrual cycle to determine the fertile window when ovulation is most likely to occur. During this fertile window, which typically spans several days around the time of ovulation, compulsory abstinence of sexual intercourse for nearly one half of every month is necessary.The length of the fertile window depends on factors such as the length and regularity of the menstrual cycle and the variability of ovulation timing.
  • The calendar method does not require the use of contraceptives or devices, so it is associated with no financial costs(Option B):. However, it may involve the cost of tracking menstrual cycles using calendars, apps, or other methods.
  • The calendar method is one of several fertility awareness-based methods (FABMs) that rely on tracking various fertility indicators, including menstrual cycle length, basal body temperature, and cervical mucus changes, to identify fertile and infertile days and hence the safe period.(Option C)
  • While ectopic pregnancy is rare, it is a potential complication of any contraceptive method, including the calendar method.Ectopic pregnancies may follow conception late in the menstrual cycle and displacement of the ovum;embryonic abnormalities may result from conception involving either an over-aged sperm or over-aged ovum(Option D).

Key Takeaways:

The drawbacks of the calendar method are :

  • a woman's menstrual cycles are not always regular. If the cycles are irregular, it is difficult to predict the safe period
  • it is only possible for this method to be used by educated and responsible couples with a high degree of motivation and cooperation
  • compulsory abstinence of sexual intercourse for nearly one half of every month - what may be called "programmed sex"
  • This method is not applicable during the postnatal period.
  • a high failure rate of 9 per 100 woman-years.The failures are due to wrong calculations, inability to follow calculations, irregular use and "taking chances"
  • Two medical complications have been reported to result from the use of safe period; ectopic pregnancies and embryonic abnormalities.

questions.text: A contraceptive method has a Pearl Index of 10, meaning it results in 10 accidental pregnancies per 100 woman-years of use. Assuming the average reproductive lifespan of a woman is 25 years, how many accidental pregnancies is an average woman expected to have while using this contraceptive method throughout her reproductive life?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Pearl index is a measure of contraceptive effectiveness that indicates the number of pregnancies per 100 woman-years of product use. In this case, the Pearl index for contraceptive C is given as 10 pregnancies per 100 woman-years (10 per HWY).

The formula to calculate the number of pregnancies per woman-year (PWY) is:

Pearl Index = ({Number of accidental Pregnancies}{Total Woman-Years of Exposure}) x 100

Therefore, Number of pregnancies=(Pearl index Total Woman-Years of Exposure) %100

= {10 25} = 2.5

Key Takeaways:

Formulas:

Pearl Index = ({Number of accidental Pregnancies}{Total Woman-Years of Exposure}) x 100

Pearl Index = ({Number of accidental Pregnancies}{Total Woman-months of Exposure}) x 12 x 100

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Long-term reversible contraceptives are contraceptive methods that provide effective contraception for an extended period but can be removed or discontinued if the individual desires to become pregnant.

Tubal sterilization, also known as tubal ligation, is a permanent method of contraception. It involves surgically blocking or sealing the fallopian tubes to prevent the sperm from reaching the egg, thus preventing fertilization.

Unlike the CuT IUD and Implanon, tubal sterilization is not reversible without undergoing a surgical procedure to attempt tubal reversal or in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment.

Explanation for other options:

CuT IUD (Copper T Intrauterine Device)(Option A):

  • The CuT IUD is a long-term reversible contraceptive method.
  • It is a small, T-shaped device inserted into the uterus that releases copper ions, which are spermicidal and prevent fertilization.

Implanon(Option B):

  • Implanon is a long-term reversible contraceptive method.
  • It is a small, flexible rod that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It releases a progestin hormone (etonogestrel) slowly over a period of up to three years, providing effective contraception.It can be removed at any time if the individual wishes to become pregnant.

LNG IUD (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine Device)(Option D):

  • The LNG IUD, such as Mirena or Kyleena, is a long-term reversible contraceptive method.
  • It is a T-shaped device that is inserted into the uterus and releases a progestin hormone (levonorgestrel) locally, which thickens cervical mucus, inhibits sperm motility, and may suppress ovulation. It provides contraception for several years but can be removed at any time, allowing for the possibility of pregnancy afterward.
